target: This meeting was the eleventh evidence session on the Children Abolition of Defense of Reasonable Publishment Wales Bill. Barry Hughes was there to answer questions related to the Bill. Six main topics that had been discussed or explained. The first one was how the Bill protected the children in terms of prosecutions. The second part explained the divergence between regions and the Bill's implication on England. The third part explained how the law was implemented, and the fourth talked about prosecutions and potential alternatives. Barry Hughes then further explained our-of-court disposals and responded to a specific infrastructure for these cases. In the last part, the meeting turned to discuss a number of unintended consequences related to the Bill.

target: This meeting was a Children, Young People and Education Committee, and it was conducted in a question and answer format regarding the inquiry into the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification. They had discussions on whether employers understood the meaning of the Welsh bac and how to actually improve the employer's understanding of the Welsh bac. Then they gave some answers regarding how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare learners for employment. In addition, they had discussions on whether there was a difference in how the Welsh bac was valued by learners at the different levels that it was studied, and to what extent that universities understood the value of the Welsh bac. They also talked about how comparable the Welsh bac was to other qualifications. Then they discussed the idea of universal adoption. Last but not least, they shared some opinions on the necessity of introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification.
prediction: The meeting discussed the implementation of the Welsh Baccalaureate (WB) in Welsh schools, with a focus on its perceived value and the impact it has on young people. Witnesses from various organizations, including educational institutions, expressed their views on the subject. They emphasized that while the WB does not have to be mandatory for all, it is essential to be an option. They noted that some people might have a negative attitude toward the WB due to their school experience. Witnesses also suggested that providing specialized trainer education could help enhance its status and reputation. The team concurred that the WB needs to go back to its original vision and provide those skills that Ed has mentioned and everything. They all supported that, but it was not quite right now. The team visited Spain recently, and they found that the entrepreneurship and enterprise unit was mandatory for everyone, but it appeared to be far more fit for purpose than the Welsh Baccalaureate is currently. Therefore, I think all of us would like to see it back to that to provide those skills that Ed has been an option.</s>

target: The meeting was taken up by discussion about a thesis proposal and a talk about to take place at EML. It was advised that more emphasis should be put on the role of construal in the understanding of metaphor and metonymy. Base constructions deal with the norm, while further general domain mechanisms determine how the constructions are invoked depending on the context. Several potential examples of polysemy were discussed in detail: "walk/run into", "on the bus", "out of film", "where is X?". However, none of them was an example of lexical polysemy resolved by construal straightforward enough to include in the proposal; the tourist domain is not metaphor rich.
